title: Sans counterpart to Goudy Oldstyle?
content:
I would love to use something else of Goudy’s, but Goudy Sans is too warm.

Is there a more impersonal sanserif that resonates with Goudy Oldstyle?

 [‹ Avant Garde Gothic for Display, what for copy?](http://web.archive.org/web/20080612044044/http:/typophile.com/node/17492 "Go to previous forum topic") [Type Battle! week of 1/16 ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080612044044/http:/typophile.com/node/17366 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Tim Brown

comments.content:
the only other sans that i know Goudy put his hand to were a bold version of [Globe Gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20080612044044/http:/www.p22.com/lanston/products/globegothic.html) and Copperplate Gothic\* but that may be a bit much. You may try something from the same period: Franklin Gothic, maybe.

\*There’s also a “Lining Gothic” which was never produced

I think [Credo](http://web.archive.org/web/20080612044044/http:/www.p22.com/rtf/Products/Credo.html) by [Jim Rimmer](http://web.archive.org/web/20080612044044/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Jim%252BRimmer) has quite a bit of Goudy influence in it.

I like Credo too, Paul. Thanks for introducing me to it. Sadly, its heavy weights have the same problem that [Apex Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20080612044044/http:/www.vllg.com/Thirstype/ApexNew/Example+About/) used to have. (see comparison at bottom)

Credo and Agenda are both great suggestions.

What do you think of E+F’s [Today Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20080612044044/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/today-sans/)?
Legacy has similar proportions and Renaissance forms.
I like Today Sans and think it would work nicely with Goudy, they are both fairly round fonts.
